So one of the things we decided that we
should tackle is that we want to
simplify the development uh for UI by
providing a good workflow. And I like to
say is that what we're doing is that
we're optimizing for developer time
because that's always probably the most
critical resource that we never have
enough of.
We also wanted to see could we reduce
the amount of boilerplate that we were
traditionally having to do when we were
creating screens. Now the reason for
this is because let's say that you have
on average 10 lines of code, 10
blueprint nodes per screen. Doesn't
sound like a lot, but take that times
150 and that's 1,500 lines. So yes,
there's a little bit of a cost to
building that, but the bigger issue is
just that when something needs to change
in that boilerplate, as the project goes
on, there are more and more places that
you need to do it.
And lastly, we needed help. Probably
about the first two years of this
development,
we only had two full-time UI engineers.
So that meant that we needed some help
from gameplay and design. Not really to
help us build screens that we were going
to ship with, but just to stand up

and start testing different features of

some of our thoughts about about the
development and workflow.
Now looking at all this, we had a
decision to make. We could either kind
of go with a more traditional approach
like uh inheritance and see could we
make that just better for scale.
Instead, we kind of took the roadless
traveled and we wanted to go with a
compositional approach. So, if you
wanted to define a component, it's that
we're taking some functionality we're
putting into a class that is very
separate from others. The metaphor
people like to use is that you're
building Lego blocks and then you can
take those blocks and put them in
different configurations in what you're
building.
And this one
choice of ours really affected pretty
much every how we did everything else in
terms of UI for the game.
And so we called this system just UICS,
user interface component system.

So, just want to define some terms so

have a screen. So, the screen is just
the base of our UI system. If there is
something visual that's UI, it's because
it's attached to a screen. Widget, you
probably most of you probably know this
because of Unreal Engine, but it's just
a visual UI element. And then we have a
control, which means that it's an
interactable widget. So think of like a
button.
And lastly, so we're going to define a
screen component. And this is a class
that provides some functionality that
you can add to a screen.
So as you're as you are adding
components to screens, you're kind of
giving them more functionality.
Now one thing about moving to components

hey, I've got these screens. How do I

this was a very big part of our

So next problem is
how how do we break UI implementation
into components? So let's think about
something like let's say an inventory

to do for that? Well, one is we have to
get data. We have to get the player's

button.
And then lastly, we need to respond to

click on an item, that can be we open a

we drop that item from the player's

So, if we break it down like that, well,
we've got three components here we could

is that it's going to retrieve data and
you can do this by you implement a data
provider which is just implementing how
you're getting the data you want. That
data is going to come back as an array
of view object pointers. The reason
being is because at this level, we don't
really need to know much about what the
specifics of the data we're retrieving
are. Whoever does get that data though,
you know, it'll be able to it should
know what to cast it to.
Um, then we have optional filters and

And when you fill everything out, it

here the players, it's then a lot less

The reason for that is because as you're

you're going to see a lot of different

For instance,

uh for when any widget that it created

Here's the widget. Here's the data. This

And when the composable widget gets

So some of the things we identified for

provide a structure and consistency like

for one component to kind of have its
functionality bleed out somewhere else.
Along with that, we found that
our when it came to our class classes,
